description: An interactive 3D MicroSim demonstrating the geometry of a soccer ball (truncated icosahedron) with 12 black pentagonal faces and 20 white hexagonal faces. Features rotation controls and explores the mathematical properties of this Archimedean solid.

learningObjectives: Understand the geometric structure of a truncated icosahedron
Identify the relationship between pentagons and hexagons in spherical tessellation
Apply Euler's formula (V - E + F = 2) to verify the soccer ball structure
Analyze why exactly 12 pentagons are needed to close a sphere
prerequisites: Familiarity with Euler's formula (helpful but not required)

accessibility: High contrast black and white design
Clear visual distinction between face types

controls.name: Rotation Speed
controls.description: Controls the speed of automatic rotation

mathematicalBasis: Golden ratio (Ï†) used for vertex coordinates
visualFeatures: 3D lighting with ambient and directional lights

keyQuestions: What shapes make up a soccer ball?
How many pentagons and hexagons are there?
Why can't a soccer ball be made of only hexagons?
How does Euler's formula apply to this shape?
commonMisconceptions: Soccer balls have equal numbers of pentagons and hexagons (they don't - 12 vs 20)
The ball could be made entirely of hexagons (it can't - curvature requires pentagons)
All faces are the same size (pentagons are smaller than hexagons)
assessmentOpportunities: Count and verify the number of each face type
Apply Euler's formula to verify the structure
Calculate total edges from face information
